  <h2 class="fragment" style ="color:teal;"> Random Sampling Technique </h2>
  <p class="fragment"> Property sample size increased from $30,000$ to $100,000$. </p>
  <ul>
    <li class="fragment">Very large sample is drawn at random,</li>
    <li class="fragment" style="color: gray">3,000+ samples are drawn randomly within each year...</li>
    <li class="fragment">but year-to-year balancing is employed to prevent sparsity</li>
  </ul>
</section>

## Random Sampling Technique:

::: {.v-center-container}
![](images/annual_distribution_of_data.png)

Sampling technique becomes:
$$ 
n_\text{year} = \frac{n}{28},
$$
where 28 is the range of years in the study.
:::

##

<section>
  <h2>Imbalance Observation:</h2>
  <p style="color:teal"> <b> Despite coastal residency rate of ~40%, empirically: </b></p>
  <ul>
    <li class="fragment">~75% of entries were non-coastal</li>
    <li class="fragment" style="color: gray">~25% of entries were coastal</li>
  </ul>

  <p class="fragment" style="color:teal"><b><em>Why?</em> Not clear. Perhaps:</b></p>
  <ul>
    <li class="fragment">Coastal urbanization means more rentals, fewer home sales per capita</li>
    <li class="fragment" style="color: gray">Coastal homeowners tend to hold their homes more often</li>
  </ul>
</section>

## Random Sampling Implication:

Amendments to the random sampling technique allow us to expect:

$$
n_\text{year, coastal} \approx \frac{100000}{28}*\frac{1}{4} \approx 900, \text{and}
$$

$$
n_\text{year, inland} \approx \frac{100000}{28}*\frac{3}{4} \approx 2700,
$$

Still satisfactory for this analysis.

  <h2 style="text-align: center;"> Now, let's test hypotheses!</h2>

<p style="color:silver; text-align: center;">$H_0$: The <b>difference</b> in the <b>average monthly rate of change</b> of home valuations between coastal and non-coastal counties is <b>zero</b>, versus</p>

<p style="color:olive; text-align: center;">$H_1$: The <b>difference</b> in the <b>average monthly rate of change</b> of valuations between coastal and non-coastal counties is <b>not zero</b>,</p>

<p> With $α = 0.05$ as our significance level. Alternatively,</p>

<p style="color:silver; text-align: center;"> $H_0: \mu_{\Delta \bar{V}_{\text{month, coastal}}}$ -
$\mu_{\Delta \bar{V}_{\text{month, inland}}}$ = 0, vs.
 </p>

<p style="color:olive; text-align: center;"> $H_1: \mu_{\Delta \bar{V}_{\text{month, coastal}}}$ -
$\mu_{\Delta \bar{V}_{\text{month, inland}}} \neq 0.$
 </p>
</section>

<section data-auto-animate>
<h2 style="color: teal; text-align: center; margin-top: 10px;">Now, let's test hypotheses!</h2>

<h2 style="text-align: center; margin-top: 10px;" class="fragment">What do we find?</h2>

<p class="fragment"> No evidence to suggest that the month-over-month rate of change for property values differs on average for coastal and inland properties (1996-2024, $p = 0.182$) </p>

<h2 style="text-align: center; margin-top: 10px; color: teal;" class="fragment"> Implications? </h2>
</section>

<section data-auto-animate>
<h2 style="text-align: center;"> Implications? </h2>

<p class="fragment"> Coastal property risks are either not priced in, and/or other market forces are muting the effects of priced climate risks. </p>
